intro: Tapinanthus discolor, commonly known as the ghost flower or parasitic orchid, is a hemiparasitic plant that relies on a host for some of its nutritional needs. It is native to arid regions of southern Africa, where it thrives in rocky or sandy soils. The plant has small, pale green leaves and produces delicate, white or pale yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. It lacks true roots and absorbs water and nutrients through its stems, which are embedded in the host plant. Due to its unique parasitic nature and striking appearance, it is often considered a rare and interesting species in botanical studies.
